A **ghost**,  , is a type of [monster](/wiki/Monster "Monster") in that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is one of two members of the [ghost](/wiki/Ghost_\(monster_class\) "Ghost (monster class)") [monster class](/wiki/Monster_class "Monster class"), along with the [shade](/wiki/Shade "Shade").

Ghosts are [undead](/wiki/Undead "Undead"), incorporeal humanoid beings that are capable of [flight](/wiki/Flight "Flight") and [phasing](/wiki/Phasing "Phasing") through walls, and will [follow](/wiki/Follow "Follow") you to other levels if adjacent. A ghost resists [cold](/wiki/Cold_resistance "Cold resistance"), [sleep](/wiki/Sleep_resistance "Sleep resistance"), [poison](/wiki/Poison_resistance "Poison resistance"), [stoning](/wiki/Stoning_resistance "Stoning resistance"), and [disintegration](/wiki/Disintegration_resistance "Disintegration resistance"); as undead, they also have [drain resistance](/wiki/Drain_resistance "Drain resistance") and [death resistance](/wiki/Death_resistance "Death resistance").

A ghost's default glyph makes them difficult to see and locate properly, e.g. via [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy") - some players use the [SYMBOLS](/wiki/Option#symset "Option") option to give ghosts and shades a different appearance, such as X or 8.

## Generation

Ghosts are not randomly generated, but appear in [graveyards](/wiki/Graveyard "Graveyard"), including the [Valley of the Dead](/wiki/Valley_of_the_Dead "Valley of the Dead")'s three large graveyards and the graveyard in [Orcus Town](/wiki/Orcus_Town "Orcus Town"). A ghost is also generated at level creation on the [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level"), in [Asmodeus' Lair](/wiki/Asmodeus%27_Lair "Asmodeus' Lair"), and in [Baalzebub's Lair](/wiki/Baalzebub%27s_Lair "Baalzebub's Lair").

In addition, a ghost will occasionally generate when you step into a haunted [temple](/wiki/Temple "Temple"), and [quaffing](/wiki/Quaff "Quaff") a [milky potion](/wiki/Milky_potion "Milky potion") may also cause a ghost to appear. Both instances will cause you to be paralyzed by fear for 3 turns, which is not blocked by [free action](/wiki/Free_action "Free action").

Ghosts are not a valid target for [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"), cannot go [extinct](/wiki/Extinct "Extinct"), and naturally [do not leave a corpse](/wiki/Corpseless "Corpseless") when killed. They are also not a valid form for [polymorph](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph").

*The following information pertains to an upcoming version ([3.7.0](/wiki/3.7.0 "3.7.0")). If this version is now released, please verify that it is still accurate, then update the page to incorporate this information.*

One of the [themed rooms](/wiki/Themed_room "Themed room") contains the ghost of an adventurer, which may be generated atop a fake bones pile of one or more items.

### Bones

- *Main article: [Bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones")*

Ghosts often appear in [bones](/wiki/Bones "Bones") levels, which are copies of levels where previous players died. Most standard causes of death for a player character will leave a ghost behind - see the article on bones files for more information and exceptions.

Player ghosts in bones files are generated asleep on top of their original inventories, and has the same name and experience level of that character; their pet(s) may be nearby, and depending on the circumstances may also be hostile. Any objects that were carried in the deceased player's main inventory have a 4⁄5 chance of becoming cursed, even if they were originally blessed. Other objects on the level and the contents of containers in the player's inventory maintain their beatitude.

### Ghost names

Ghosts in bones files are named after the dead adventurer they represent. The ghost generated on the [Rogue level](/wiki/Rogue_level "Rogue level") is named *Michael Toy*, *Kenneth Arnold*, or *Glenn Wichman*. Ghosts created on other special levels have a 1⁄7 chance of being given the name of your character, or else of another character from the score list. Otherwise, they are given a random name from the following list:[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

Named ghosts are special-cased to be referred to as *\<name>'s ghost* rather than *\<name>*, but their names are otherwise treated as ordinary names given by the #[call](/wiki/Call "Call") command, and they can be renamed like other monsters.

## Strategy

Ghosts are *very* slow and do very little damage, but they possess a very low AC, and will likely evade most attacks unless you have a decently enchanted weapon. Their [MR score](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)") of 50 also makes using certain kinds of magic against them somewhat difficult. If you meet one in the early game and cannot reliably dispatch them via regular attacks, using ray-type wands and spells can do the job - if all else fails, [kicking](/wiki/Kicking "Kicking") the ghost will eventually bring them down.

In most scenarios involving a bones pile, the player ghost can be led away with little trouble, especially if you plan to use certain wands such as a [wand of fire](/wiki/Wand_of_fire "Wand of fire") to destroy the ghost. Be sure not to forget about their original killer or their pets, or you may well [become a ghost yourself](/wiki/YASD "YASD").

### Turning

Ghosts are affected by the [turn undead](/wiki/Turn_undead "Turn undead") spell and [extended command](/wiki/Extended_command "Extended command") like other undead. However, if you successfully [revive](/wiki/Revive "Revive") the corpse of a dead player character while their ghost is on or next to its square, the ghost will be pulled into the corpse on the item pile, leaving behind a [confused](/wiki/Confused "Confused") monster. This also works if the corpse is not of a standard playable race, provided the target was killed while [polymorphed](/wiki/Polymorph "Polymorph") into that form (e.g., wearing an [amulet of unchanging](/wiki/Amulet_of_unchanging "Amulet of unchanging")). If the ghost is [tame](/wiki/Tame "Tame"), then the resulting monster will be tame, and is otherwise generated peaceful or hostile as normal based on your [alignment](/wiki/Alignment "Alignment") and race.

## History

The ghost first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, which are based on [Jay Fenlason's Hack](/wiki/Jay_Fenlason%27s_Hack "Jay Fenlason's Hack"), and is included in the initial bestiary for [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"). In Hack 1.21, the ghost uses the [apostrophe](/wiki/Apostrophe "Apostrophe") glyph, '; in Hack for PDP-11, they are somehow coded to use a tab-key character. In [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"), the ghost uses its current glyph.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Ghost](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghost "wikipedia:Ghost")***

A ghost is the soul or spirit of a dead person or animal that is believed to be able to appear to the living. Descriptions of ghosts vary widely, from an invisible presence to translucent or barely visible wispy shapes to realistic, lifelike forms. The belief in the existence of an afterlife, as well as manifestations of the spirits of the dead, is widespread, dating back to animism or ancestor worship in pre-literate cultures. Certain religious practices—funeral rites, exorcisms, and some practices of spiritualism and ritual magic—are specifically designed to rest the spirits of the dead.

Ghosts are generally described as solitary, human-like essences, though stories of ghostly armies and the ghosts of animals other than humans have also been recounted. They are believed to haunt particular locations, objects, or people they were associated with in life, either to communicate with the living or to seek vengeance for past wrongs.

## Messages

- \<Name>'s ghost is suddenly drawn into its former body!

  A wand or spell of turn undead revived the corpse of a dead player character by reuniting the ghost with its former body.

## Variants

In variants that include the [Convict](/wiki/Convict "Convict") role, 1-3 ghosts are generated at level creation for each of the upper filler levels in the [Convict quest](/wiki/Convict_quest "Convict quest"). In variants that include the [Pirate](/wiki/Pirate "Pirate") role, several appear on the [Pirate quest](/wiki/Pirate_quest "Pirate quest") upon the creation of certain levels: three on the home level, one in each upper filler level, four in the locate level, and three in each lower filler level.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), the [Lawful Quest](/wiki/Lawful_Quest "Lawful Quest") has two spots within the Boulder Path section where a ghost can be generated on level creation, with a 3⁄5 chance for each square. Another ghost appears in the prisons of [Grund's Stronghold](/wiki/Grund%27s_Stronghold "Grund's Stronghold").

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), ghosts use . as a glyph, making them slightly more visible normally and easier to spot via [telepathy](/wiki/Telepathy "Telepathy").

Ghosts may appear in the audience of a [throne room](/wiki/Throne_room "Throne room") [ruled by a](/wiki/Special_room_\(dNetHack\)#Throne_room_.28throne_occupied.29 "Special room (dNetHack)") [vampire lord](/wiki/Vampire_lord "Vampire lord").

### xNetHack

In [xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack"), ghosts are now part of the ​W [wraith](/wiki/Wraith_\(monster_class\) "Wraith (monster class)") monster class.

The ghost's base level is reduced to 4, their speed is increased to 5, their AC is increased to 5, and their magic resistance score is increased to 80. Similar to shades, ghosts can only be hit by magic, blessed or sufficiently-enchanted weapons, [artifact weapons](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon"), or objects made of silver or bone; unlike shades, ghosts are not silver-haters.

1⁄3 of ghosts will generate [invisible](/wiki/Invisible "Invisible"). Instead of solely relying on a touch attack, a ghost will also turn invisible every so often and try to frighten their target by reappearing next to them, which paralyzes that monster for three turns. This cannot prevented by free action, but fails if the player is able to [see invisible](/wiki/See_invisible "See invisible") or otherwise sense the invisible ghost.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), ghosts can [grow up](/wiki/Grow_up "Grow up") into [spectres](/wiki/Spectre "Spectre").

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), ghosts have their behavior and properties altered similar to xNetHack, though their glyph and monster class are not changed.

The ghost's base level is increased to 7, their speed is increased to 5, their AC is improved to 0, and their magic resistance score is increased to 80. Ghosts can only be hit by magic, weapon that are blessed or else sufficiently-enchanted (i.e. at least +2), artifact weapons, or objects made of silver or bone.

As in xNetHack, instead of solely relying on a touch attack, a ghost will also turn invisible every so often and try to frighten their target by reappearing next to them, which paralyzes that monster for three turns. This is not prevented by free action, but fails if the player is can see invisible or otherwise senses the invisible ghost.

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, ghosts now use 8 as their glyph.

## Encyclopedia entry

And now the souls of the dead who had gone below came swarming up from Erebus -- fresh brides, unmarried youths, old men with life's long suffering behind them, tender young girls still nursing this first anguish in their hearts, and a great throng of warriors killed in battle, their spear-wounds gaping yet and all their armor stained with blood. From this multitude of souls, as they fluttered to and fro by the trench, there came a moaning that was horrible to hear. Panic drained the blood from my cheeks.

\[ The Odyssey, (chapter Lambda), by Homer ]

This is not prevented by free action, but fails if the player is can see invisible or otherwise senses the invisible ghost.

SlashTHEM

In SlashTHEM, in addition to SLASH'EM details, ghosts now use 8 as their glyph.

A '''ghost''', {{monsym|ghost}}, is a type of [[monster]] in that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is one of two members of the [[ghost (monster class)|ghost]] [[monster class]], along with the [[shade]].

Ghosts are [[undead]], incorporeal humanoid beings that are capable of [[flight]] and [[phasing]] through walls, and will [[follow]] you to other levels if adjacent. A ghost resists [[Cold resistance|cold]], [[Sleep resistance|sleep]], [[Poison resistance|poison]], [[Stoning resistance|stoning]], and [[Disintegration resistance|disintegration]]; as undead, they also have [[drain resistance]] and [[death resistance]].

A ghost's default glyph makes them difficult to see and locate properly, e.g. via [[telepathy]] - some players use the [[Option#symset|SYMBOLS]] option to give ghosts and shades a different appearance, such as {{white|X}} or {{white|8}}.

==Generation==
Ghosts are not randomly generated, but appear in [[graveyard]]s, including the [[Valley of the Dead]]'s three large graveyards and the graveyard in [[Orcus Town]]. A ghost is also generated at level creation on the [[Rogue level]], in [[Asmodeus' Lair]], and in [[Baalzebub's Lair]]. 

In addition, a ghost will occasionally generate when you step into a haunted [[temple]], and [[quaff]]ing a [[milky potion]] may also cause a ghost to appear. Both instances will cause you to be paralyzed by fear for 3 turns, which is not blocked by [[free action]].

Ghosts are not a valid target for [[genocide]], cannot go [[extinct]], and naturally [[Corpseless|do not leave a corpse]] when killed. They are also not a valid form for [[polymorph]].

{{upcoming|3.7.0|One of the [[themed room]]s contains the ghost of an adventurer, which may be generated atop a fake bones pile of one or more items.}}

===Bones===
{{main|Bones}}
Ghosts often appear in [[bones]] levels, which are copies of levels where previous players died. Most standard causes of death for a player character will leave a ghost behind - see the article on bones files for more information and exceptions.

Player ghosts in bones files are generated asleep on top of their original inventories, and has the same name and experience level of that character; their pet(s) may be nearby, and depending on the circumstances may also be hostile. Any objects that were carried in the deceased player's main inventory have a {{frac|4|5}} chance of becoming cursed, even if they were originally blessed. Other objects on the level and the contents of containers in the player's inventory maintain their beatitude.

===Ghost names===
Ghosts in bones files are named after the dead adventurer they represent. The ghost generated on the [[Rogue level]] is named ''Michael Toy'', ''Kenneth Arnold'', or ''Glenn Wichman''. Ghosts created on other special levels have a {{frac|7}} chance of being given the name of your character, or else of another character from the score list. Otherwise, they are given a random name from the following list:{{reffunc|do_name.c|rndghostname}}{{refsrc|src/do_name.c|1603|nethack=3.6.7}}

Named ghosts are special-cased to be referred to as ''<name>'s ghost'' rather than ''<name>'', but their names are otherwise treated as ordinary names given by the #[[call]] command, and they can be renamed like other monsters.

==Strategy==
Ghosts are ''very'' slow and do very little damage, but they possess a very low AC, and will likely evade most attacks unless you have a decently enchanted weapon. Their [[Magic resistance (monster)|MR score]] of 50 also makes using certain kinds of magic against them somewhat difficult. If you meet one in the early game and cannot reliably dispatch them via regular attacks, using ray-type wands and spells can do the job - if all else fails, [[kicking]] the ghost will eventually bring them down.

In most scenarios involving a bones pile, the player ghost can be led away with little trouble, especially if you plan to use certain wands such as a [[wand of fire]] to destroy the ghost. Be sure not to forget about their original killer or their pets, or you may well [[YASD|become a ghost yourself]].

===Turning===
Ghosts are affected by the [[turn undead]] spell and [[extended command]] like other undead. However, if you successfully [[revive]] the corpse of a dead player character while their ghost is on or next to its square, the ghost will be pulled into the corpse on the item pile, leaving behind a [[confused]] monster. This also works if the corpse is not of a standard playable race, provided the target was killed while [[polymorph]]ed into that form (e.g., wearing an [[amulet of unchanging]]). If the ghost is [[tame]], then the resulting monster will be tame, and is otherwise generated peaceful or hostile as normal based on your [[alignment]] and race.

==History==
The ghost first appears in Hack 1.21 and Hack for PDP-11, which are based on [[Jay Fenlason's Hack]], and is included in the initial bestiary for [[Hack 1.0]]. In Hack 1.21, the ghost uses the [[apostrophe]] glyph, {{white|'}}; in Hack for PDP-11, they are somehow coded to use a tab-key character. In [[Hack 1.0]], the ghost uses its current glyph.

==Origin==
{{Wikipedia|Ghost}}
A ghost is the soul or spirit of a dead person or animal that is believed to be able to appear to the living. Descriptions of ghosts vary widely, from an invisible presence to translucent or barely visible wispy shapes to realistic, lifelike forms. The belief in the existence of an afterlife, as well as manifestations of the spirits of the dead, is widespread, dating back to animism or ancestor worship in pre-literate cultures. Certain religious practices—funeral rites, exorcisms, and some practices of spiritualism and ritual magic—are specifically designed to rest the spirits of the dead.

Ghosts are generally described as solitary, human-like essences, though stories of ghostly armies and the ghosts of animals other than humans have also been recounted. They are believed to haunt particular locations, objects, or people they were associated with in life, either to communicate with the living or to seek vengeance for past wrongs.

==Messages==
{{message|<Name>'s ghost is suddenly drawn into its former body!|A wand or spell of turn undead revived the corpse of a dead player character by reuniting the ghost with its former body.}}

==Variants==
In variants that include the [[Convict]] role, 1-3 ghosts are generated at level creation for each of the upper filler levels in the [[Convict quest]]. In variants that include the [[Pirate]] role, several appear on the [[Pirate quest]] upon the creation of certain levels: three on the home level, one in each upper filler level, four in the locate level, and three in each lower filler level.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], the [[Lawful Quest]] has two spots within the Boulder Path section where a ghost can be generated on level creation, with a {{frac|3|5}} chance for each square. Another ghost appears in the prisons of [[Grund's Stronghold]].

===dNetHack===
In [[dNetHack]], ghosts use {{gray|.}} as a glyph, making them slightly more visible normally and easier to spot via [[telepathy]].

Ghosts may appear in the audience of a [[throne room]] [[Special room (dNetHack)#Throne room (throne occupied)|ruled by a]] [[vampire lord]].

===xNetHack===
In [[xNetHack]], ghosts are now part of the {{monclass|W}} monster class.

The ghost's base level is reduced to 4, their speed is increased to 5, their AC is increased to 5, and their magic resistance score is increased to 80. Similar to shades, ghosts can only be hit by magic, blessed or sufficiently-enchanted weapons, [[artifact weapon]]s, or objects made of silver or bone; unlike shades, ghosts are not silver-haters.

{{frac|3}} of ghosts will generate [[invisible]]. Instead of solely relying on a touch attack, a ghost will also turn invisible every so often and try to frighten their target by reappearing next to them, which paralyzes that monster for three turns. This cannot prevented by free action, but fails if the player is able to [[see invisible]] or otherwise sense the invisible ghost.

===SpliceHack===
In [[SpliceHack]], ghosts can [[grow up]] into [[spectre]]s.

===EvilHack===
In [[EvilHack]], ghosts have their behavior and properties altered similar to xNetHack, though their glyph and monster class are not changed.

The ghost's base level is increased to 7, their speed is increased to 5, their AC is improved to 0, and their magic resistance score is increased to 80. Ghosts can only be hit by magic, weapon that are blessed or else sufficiently-enchanted (i.e. at least +2), artifact weapons, or objects made of silver or bone.

As in xNetHack, instead of solely relying on a touch attack, a ghost will also turn invisible every so often and try to frighten their target by reappearing next to them, which paralyzes that monster for three turns. This is not prevented by free action, but fails if the player is can see invisible or otherwise senses the invisible ghost.

===SlashTHEM===
In [[SlashTHEM]], in addition to SLASH'EM details, ghosts now use {{gray|8}} as their glyph.
